<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>How is Russell using the term "idleness"?</Question>
<Question type="reading-discussion" level={2}>Do you think he means "no activity" or does he have in mind certain kinds of activities that distinct from "non-idle activities"?</Question>
<Question type="reading-discussion" level={2}>Can you think of an example of the kinds of "idle activities" he has in mind?</Question>
<Question type="reading-discussion" level={2}>Why does he see value in these kinds of activities?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>What is Russell's primary proposal? What does he think is new about the modern era that makes this proposal possible?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>Can you identify the distinct objections to this proposal that he lists?</Question>
<Question type="reading-discussion" level={2}>Which objection struck you as the most compelling and why? (Be ready to share.)</Question>
<Question level={1}>How does he answer that objection?</Question>
<Question type="reading-discussion" level={2}>Do you find his response convincing? Why or why not?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

<QuestionBlock type="reading-discussion">
<Question level={1}>
Imagine an employer offers you the following proposal: You can either work a 20-hour work week and get paid $50,000 a year or you can work a 60-hour work week for $80,000. Identify which choice you think you would make and why? 
</Question>
<Question level={2}>Does Russell’s argument motivate you to choose the 20-hour work week? Why or why not?</Question>
<Question level={2}>Be attentive to the details of how you are making this choice. What ultimate activities or goals do you have in view? What other factors influence your decision besides these target activities or goals?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

posts.content: What do you think is Meno's basic difficulty at the opening of this dialogue? Why is he not able to define virtue? How does this difficulty illustrate the difference between a definition and instances of that definition (70a-80d)? As Socrates turns to look for his own definition of virtue, what objection does he face (80d-e)? How does he attempt to answer that objection? (Hint: what does he mean by recollection?) (81b-82a) How does Socrates try to illustrate his theory of recollection through his interaction with the slave boy (82b and following)? To help you understand this complicated exchange note that Plato is trying to get the slave boy to recognize the following geometrical truth: A square (BEHD) whose area is twice that of a given square (ABCD) is the square (BEHD) formed using the diagonal of the square (ABCD) as one of its four sides. {/* */} During the exchange, does Socrates ever teach the boy or give the boy new information? Or does the boy discover everything for himself? Can you think of other examples of this kind of learning? Can you think of an example where you must have already known "something", but if someone had asked you before, you would have probably said you didn't know it? What is the difference between knowledge and opinion that begins to be discussed at 97b? How does Socrates illustrate this difference with his obscure reference to the statues of Daedalus and runaway slaves? How does one "tie" down an opinion so that it becomes knowledge (98a)? If holding a "true opinion/belief" means that we believe what is true (that is, we have an accurate belief about the world), why do we need something called "knowledge"? In Plato's terms, why is better to have a true opinion that has been "tied down"? Can you think of some concrete situations where "true opinion" might not be sufficient, perhaps a situation where having "true opinion" but not knowledge is dangerous or simply unsatisfying?

<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
  <Question level={1}>How does Aristotle begin to address the Meno problem in the very first line of this reading (71a)?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>
<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
  <Question level={1}>In Book 1, c. 1, how is Aristotle using the language of the universal and the particular to explain the acquisition of knowledge?</Question>
  <Question level={2}>How does he illustrate this in the case of a triangle?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>
<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
  <Question level={1}>At 71a25 Aristotle addresses the Meno problem directly. How does he attempt to solve this problem by introducing different senses of knowing?</Question>
  <Question level={2} type="reading-discussion">In your view, is there a particular premise in the formal argument of the Learner's Paradox (the formal argument we sketched on the board in class) that Aristotle seems to be challenging?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>
<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
  <Question level={1}>At the beginning of chapter 2 Aristotle begins to rigorously define "knowledge" in the strict and technical sense.</Question>
  <Question level={2}>How does he define knowledge? How is it distinct from mere “true opinion”?</Question>
  <Question level={2}>What is a demonstration? How does it relate to knowledge?</Question>
  <Question level={2}>What are the requirements of a demonstration? <Answer>(Hint: There are at least 6 requirements mentioned.)</Answer></Question>
</QuestionBlock>
<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
  <Question level={1}>According to chapter 3, does Aristotle think knowledge acquired through demonstration is the only kind of knowledge?</Question>
  <Question level={2}>Why or why not?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>
<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
  <Question level={1}>While chapter 4 is quite difficult, see if you can tell what kind of propositions are used in a genuine demonstration.
</Question>
</QuestionBlock>
<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
  <Question level={1}>In Book II, c. 19, is Aristotle talking about deduction or induction?</Question>
  <Question level={2}>What are the stages from which one rises from the sensation and perception of a particular to a universal concept and/or principle? <Answer>(See esp. 99b35-100a9.)</Answer></Question>
  <Question level={2} type="reading-discussion">Why does this suggest that Plato's idea of recollection is no longer needed?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>
